passages.text: The left hemisphere's world is a representation—a useful map. The right hemisphere's world is the territory itself.
Attention is not just another cognitive function. It is the way in which we bring the world into being.
The left hemisphere is like a hall of mirrors—it knows only what it already knows.
The right hemisphere sees things in context, the left hemisphere sees things as isolated and abstracted from context.
The left hemisphere is always certain. The right hemisphere is always uncertain—because it knows that certainty is a simplification.
The emissary has forgotten that it is an emissary. It has come to believe that it is the master.
We have created a world that the left hemisphere loves: one of categories, quantities, abstractions. But it is a world that is dying because it has been drained of meaning.
The more we rely on explicit knowledge, the more we lose touch with implicit understanding—which is where wisdom lives.
Music, metaphor, and the living body—these are the right hemisphere's native languages.
The left hemisphere's world is a world of things. The right hemisphere's world is a world of beings—of presences.
Reason is necessary, but it is not sufficient. It must return to the whole from which it was abstracted.
The left hemisphere thinks it knows what it is looking at. The right hemisphere is always open to being surprised.
Betweenness is fundamental to reality. Neither the subject alone nor the object alone—but the relationship between them.
The brain is not a computer. It is an organ of encounter—a way of being present to the world.
We have become so good at manipulating the world that we have forgotten how to inhabit it.
The left hemisphere is drawn to what is fixed, isolated, and certain. The right hemisphere is drawn to what is flowing, connected, and alive.
Metaphor is not a decoration on language. It is the way the right hemisphere thinks—and the way reality actually is.
The part cannot understand the whole. But it can deny that there is a whole, and increasingly, that is what the left hemisphere does.
What we attend to, and how we attend to it, determines what reality we experience.
The living world cannot be captured in categories. The attempt to do so kills it—and leaves only a corpse that can be examined.
